title: Ted Baker founder Ray Kelvin’s fortune hit by share price plunge
text:
Ted Baker founder Ray Kelvin saw his paper fortune crumble today as the retailer he left after its Hug-gate scandal slumped into the red.

Shares in the quirky fashion brand plunged 36% or 333p to 592p as it posted grim first-half results, wiping £52 million of the paper value of Kelvin’s stake.

The entrepreneur left earlier this year after allegations of inappropriate behaviour including forced hugs but remains the company’s largest shareholder and is reportedly eyeing a bid to take it private following a slump in the share price.

The retailer reported a 0.7% fall in group revenues to £303.8 million and it tumbled to a £23 million first-half loss from a £24.5 million profit during the same period last year. Same-store sales fell 2.9% while ecommerce sales were also down,

The company blamed a cocktail of problems including poor trading due to Brexit uncertainty, heavy discounting from trouble rivals and shoppers increasingly buying online. Unseasonably warm weather last month added insult to injury.

Chief executive Lindsay Page said: “We’ve got the macroeconomic and political things that are going on that are affecting consumer confidence here, in mainland Europe and the US. And that challenge to demand has led to levels of discounting certainly in this country that we’ve not seen before – some brands are going on sale at the launch of their new collections.”

Cold weather in North America and Europe also hit trading: “We probably went a bit too summery a bit too early but we addressed that quickly,” said Page.

He refused to comment on Kelvin’s rumoured potential offer.

Some analysts remained confident this wasn’t the onset of a terminal decline at Ted Baker.

Liberum analyst Adam Tomlinson said: “There has been an unprecedented level of discounting, consumer confidence remains low and other fashion players are fighting for their lives, so the fact that Ted Baker has found things tough is not surprising.

"Underlying the fall in profit, the group has done a good job in clearing excess stock, which has impacted margins in the first half, and it has bought well for the rest of the year. It remains a strong brand with international opportunity, which means it’s better placed than many to ride things out.”
